text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

MICHELLE CHRISTIE:
I am five years old.
- I am five.
MICHELLE CHRISTIE: Good.

When I started No Limits,
I was a resource teacher
for children with hearing loss.

I met this beautiful
little boy named John.

He had about 50 vocabulary
words, so he was behind.

JOHN AUTRY: It
was so frustrating

because I didn't have a
lot of friends around me.

MICHELLE CHRISTIE: And
I would sit next to him

on the little round
circle carpet,

and I'd look over at
him, and he'd have
these eyes filled with tears.
It was just so sad.

And I knew sometimes
he knew the answer,
and he wouldn't raise his hand.

I couldn't figure
out what to do.

So I got my little
boombox, and I brought
this little fake microphone.

I go, will you teach
me how to dance?

JOHN AUTRY: And I
grabbed the microphone,

and she turned it on,
and I saw her dancing
a Michael Jackson moonwalk.

It make me feel,
like, confident.

MICHELLE CHRISTIE:
All of a sudden,

he's, like, lightened
up a little bit.

And we had a connection
through music.

And then he started to
talk a little bit more.

And I just remember
thinking, we're
going to have to write a play.

We did our first production
in the summer of 1996.

JOHN AUTRY: It
was so incredible.

It made me feel that I could
be anything I want to be.
Like, go to school.
Anything I wanted to be.
I want to be an actor.

I have done 25 different
productions with No Limits.
I have done several TV shows.

I was on "Glee" with the deaf
and hard of hearing choir.

We played this song called
"Imagine" by John Lennon.
It was so emotional.

(SINGING) Imagine
all the people.
--amazing.
It was like, wow.

MICHELLE CHRISTIE: When
our parents come in,
they're just lost and confused.
I can say, John, come here.

And then he'll come in with
his big beautiful smile

and say hi and
introduce himself.

And they're like,
oh, oh, my gosh.
It's possible.
My kid's going to be OK.
JOHN AUTRY: Good job.

MICHELLE CHRISTIE:
And isn't that

what every parent wants to know,
is that they're going to be OK?
